Orientations and the Thom Isomorphism

1. Introduction

In this note we provide an introduction the Thom isomorphism and some of its important consequences following the work of Milnor and Stasheff in their book on Characteristic Classes[1]. We begin with a discussion on oriented bundles before surveying the Thom isomorphism, Euler classes, Thom spaces, and Stiefel-Whitney classes.

Notation: Throughout we write for the Eilenberg-MacLane spectrum of a ring (or more generally abelian group) . If is a vector bundle, we write for the corresponding total space.

Orientations and Oriented Bundles

To motivate our definition of an orientation for a vector bundle let's begin with a single vector space.

Orientation on a vector space

Let be a real vector space of dimension . An orientation of is an equivalence class of bases, where two (ordered) bases and are equivalent if and only if their change of basis matrix has positive determinant.

Every vector space has two distinct orientations. We often equip with its canonical orientation given by the equivalence class containing the standard ordered basis .

Previously we've discussed orientations in the context of simplices when defining simplicial and singular homology in Basics of Homology - Simplicial and Singular HomologyBasics of Homology - Simplicial and Singular Homology. To see how these are related, let be an -simplex which is linearly embedded in the -dimensional vector space with ordered vertices . Then forms a basis on corresponding to an orientation of the vector space.

We can interpret a choice of orientation for as a choice of one of the two possible generators for the singular homology groups
To see this let denote the standard -simplex with canonically ordered vertices. Choose some orientation preserving linear embedding which maps the barycenter of to the zero vector, and hence the boundary of into . Then is a singular -simplex representing an element in the group of relative -cycles . The homology class of this -cycle is now the preferred generator for the homology group .

Similarly, using dual bases we obtain a preferred generator of the cohomology group . We could also use a LES argument as in the following:

Let's now generalize to a vector bundle of fiber dimension , and give a first naive definition of orientation.

Orientation on a Vector Bundle #1

An orientation for is a function assigning an orientation to each fiber of subject to the following local compatibility:

  • For every , there exists a local trivialization with and such that for each fiber over , the homomorphism is orientation preserving.

In terms of cohomology this says that to each fiber there is assigned a preferred generator
The local compatibility condition implies that for each point in the base space, there exists a neighborhood and a cohomology class
so that for each fiber over , the restriction
In particular, these glue to give a Thom class . Moving forward we will write for without the zero section.

Alternatively, recall that if is a vector bundle over of rank , we have its exterior power which is a line bundle over . Then a compatible choice of orientations is equivalent to a compatible choice of non-zero elements in the fibers for . Thus, is orientable in the above sense if and only if admits a non-vanishing section, and hence is a trivial line bundle. In this case, any two non-vanishing sections are said to be equivalent if there exists , , such that ( can be chosen to be smooth if and are). This gives a second definition for orientations:

Orientation on a Vector Bundle #2

An orientation for is an equivalence class of non-vanishing sections .

When , for a smooth manifold, this recovers the usual orientation of manifolds.

Using our cocycle classification of bundlescocycle classification of bundles, a vector bundle being orientable can be equivalently phrased as asking for the existence of a cocycle taking values in . This is the first case of a more general pattern of lifting the cocycle group for a bundle to give it additional structure.

Orientation via Cocycles

Let be a vector bundle of rank on a space admitting partitions of unity (e.g. paracompact Hausdorff). Then admits a non-vanishing section if and only if admits a description in terms of cocycles taking values in .

Proof.
First, suppose is orientable so we have a global non-vanishing section . Say that a local frame is positively oriented if for all , for . All local frames are either positively or negatively oriented, and multiplying by in one of the coordinates we can always replace a negatively oriented local frame by a positively oriented local frame. Then we obtain our desired cover by positive local trivializations.

Conversely, if such local trivializations with cocycles exist, then we can define by taking a partition of unity and summing the induced orientations on the .
***

Another example of this phenomena occurs with Riemannian metrics, where admits a Riemannian metric if and only if it admits a cocycle with values in the orthogonal group . Over paracompact spaces this always holds via a partition of unity argument. Proof.

2.1. Steifel-Whitney Classes

Steifel-Whitney classes will be the beginning of a foray into the theory of characteristic classes which plays an essential role in the homological study of vector bundles. We will classify the axioms characterizing the Stiefel-Whitney cohomology classes of a vector bundle, of which the existence of such classes relies on the Thom isomorphism proven above.

For this subsection we will assume coefficients throughout, unless otherwise stated.
